author: By Emily Flitter and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Russia Could Use Cryptocurrency to Blunt the Force of U.S. Sanctions
description: Russian companies have many cryptocurrency tools at their disposal to evade sanctions, including a so-called digital ruble and ransomware.
content: When the United States barred Americans from doing business with Russian banks, oil and gas developers and other companies in 2014, after the country’s invasion of Crimea, the hit to Russia’s economy was swift and immense. Economists estimated that sanctions imposed by Western nations cost Russia $50 billion a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks Strategy for Responding to Union Elections Is Dealt a Setback
description: The National Labor Relations Board ruled that single Starbucks stores, not multiple locations in an area, were the proper jurisdictions for unionization votes.
content: The National Labor Relations Board dealt a blow to Starbucks’s legal strategy in response to a growing union campaign on Wednesday, rejecting the company’s argument that workers seeking to unionize in a geographic area must vote in a single union election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Prominent Regional Theater Will Exit Its Stage to Explore Its City
description: Long Wharf Theater, a regional nonprofit on New Haven’s waterfront, is ending a long, bumpy chapter there, hoping to expand access and reduce costs.
content: New Haven’s Long Wharf Theater will move out of its longtime headquarters and embrace itinerancy as the company seeks a fresh start after a period of extraordinary upheaval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Met Buys Italian Renaissance Bronze After Two Decades on the Hunt
description: The purchase of a roundel for $23 million is the museum’s second largest ever, and fulfills a former curator’s dream after losing out in a 2003 auction.
content: Nearly 20 years ago, a curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art led efforts to acquire an Italian Renaissance roundel that dates back to about 1500. That attempt failed when the museum was outbid during an auction in 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: A Groundbreaking Cartoon Family Returns, ‘Louder and Prouder’
description: “The Proud Family: Louder and Prouder,” on Disney+, revives a beloved animated series for a new generation.
content: When “The Proud Family” debuted on the Disney Channel on Sept. 15, 2001, it introduced one of TV’s first animated African American families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Climate Scientists Warn of a ‘Global Wildfire Crisis’
description: Worsening heat and dryness could lead to a 50 percent rise in off-the-charts fires, according to a United Nations report.
content: A landmark United Nations report has concluded that the risk of devastating wildfires around the world will surge in coming decades as climate change further intensifies what the report described as a “global wildfire crisis.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tamryn Spruill and Bridget Bennett
title: Women’s Basketball Players Get a New Lifeline, Close to Home
description: The five-week Athletes Unlimited season has given some players an alternative to playing overseas during the W.N.B.A. off-season and a way to earn extra money.
content: Lauren Manis was drafted, and waived, by the Las Vegas Aces before the 2020 W.N.B.A. season. She then signed with a team in Belgium, where intermittent lockdowns because of the coronavirus pandemic left her stuck in her apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: The Oscars’ Popularity Crisis
description: Why academy efforts like trimming awards from the telecast won’t help. People watch because it’s a show about elite work, not in spite of it.
content: Hollywood has conditioned me to accept some nips and tucks, but what should I do when the Oscars venture into the realm of the extreme makeover?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Peek: Gonzaga Remains the Favorite, but the Blue Bloods Are Back
description: Transfers and first-year coaches will play a key role in who cuts down the nets in New Orleans in April.
content: The N.F.L. and college football have crowned their champions, with the Los Angeles Rams and the University of Georgia winning titles. The Winter Olympics are in the rearview mirror. And the start of the Major League Baseball season is in flux because of a lockout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Learning ‘English,’ When Your Accent Is a ‘War Crime’
description: In a rich new play by Sanaz Toossi, four Iranians and their language teacher find second selves in a second tongue.
content: If you’ve ever tried, as an adult, to learn a new language, you know how painful it can be; it’s bad enough to hear yourself mangling Italian, but worse to hear it mangling you. For those of us accustomed to sounding sharp with our words, it can come as quite a blow to discover the shabby figure we cut in the ill-fitting suit of someone else’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: With some seeing parallels to Ukraine, Taiwan steps up its defenses.
description: Some analysts worry that a weak global response to Ukraine could embolden China’s Communist Party to ramp up pressure on self-governed Taiwan.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, on Wednesday ordered the island’s armed forces and security personnel to step up surveillance and strengthen defenses as she sought to reassure those who see, in the Ukraine conflict, echoes of the self-governed territory’s own existential crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich, Kate Christobek and Nate Schweber
title: 2 Prosecutors Leading N.Y. Trump Inquiry Resign, Clouding Case’s Future
description: The resignations came after the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin Bragg, was said to have expressed doubts about the case.
content: The two prosecutors leading the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation into former President Donald J. Trump and his business practices abruptly resigned on Wednesday amid a monthlong pause in their presentation of evidence to a grand jury, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: For Some in England, End of Virus Rules Threatens More Isolation
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is abolishing Covid regulations to move “back towards normality.” But people at high risk from the disease say the move will constrict their lives instead.
content: LONDON — The coronavirus forced Christopher Riley, a 53-year-old with blood cancer who lives in London, to strike a balance in the pursuit of normalcy. He would grab flowers from the buckets next to the entrance of a supermarket, but keep it quick. He went to Tate Modern, but on an early weekday morning. He would cook for friends, but only a small group who had all taken Covid tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl
title: New satellite images show military deployments continuing along the Ukrainian border.
description: One week after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced a partial withdrawal of troops from the border with Ukraine, newly released satellite images show a different reality. In addition to redeployments in the Belgorod-Valuyki area in western Russia, where there has been a lot of military activity over recent days, new military activities continue to emerge in Belarus.
content: One week after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced a partial withdrawal of troops from the border with Ukraine, newly released satellite images show a different reality. In addition to redeployments in the Belgorod-Valuyki area in western Russia, where there has been a lot of military activity over recent days, new military activities continue to emerge in Belarus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Many Russians Feel a Deep Unease Over Going to War
description: After months of tuning out American warnings that Vladimir Putin was preparing to invade Ukraine, Russians now realize that “this is not a game.”
content: Follow our live coverage on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Olsen
title: The Italian Fashion Family Diaspora
description: Increasingly the children of the most famous brands are going their own ways.
content: MILAN — When Alice Etro was a little girl, she used to spend after-school hours with her father, Kean Etro, creative director of Etro men’s wear, playing with fabric samples in the design studio of the fashion brand that her grandfather Gimmo started in 1968. She’d create garments from off-cuts for her dolls and play with the tubes from the rolls of cloth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: requisition
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word requisition has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 13 in “Amtrak Worker Sold Railroad Equipment for Years to Line His Pockets, U.S. Says” by Jesus Jiménez:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Rare Retrial Begins in Killing of American in Greece
description: Bakari Henderson, of Texas, was beaten to death in 2017. The men convicted in his case were found guilty of assault, but prosecutors are trying again with murder charges.
content: ATHENS — In the summer of 2017, Bakari Henderson, a 22-year-old American student, was beaten to death on the Greek holiday island of Zakynthos. The men convicted in Mr. Henderson’s case were initially charged with murder, but a court instead found them guilty of assault and most have served their sentences and been released.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Holder, Allison McCann, Scott Reinhard and Michael Schwirtz
title: How Russian troops closed in on Ukraine.
description: Since October, Russia has been building an enormous military force along Ukraine’s border, with as many as 190,000 troops in or near Ukraine, according to American and Ukrainian officials. The Russian troop presence has grown in recent weeks from scattered groupings parked at military bases and training grounds to battle-ready units arrayed in tactical formations. They appear prepared to attack Ukraine from three directions, according to military analysts: the north, east and south.
content: Since October, Russia has been building an enormous military force along Ukraine’s border, with as many as 190,000 troops in or near Ukraine, according to American and Ukrainian officials. The Russian troop presence has grown in recent weeks from scattered groupings parked at military bases and training grounds to battle-ready units arrayed in tactical formations. They appear prepared to attack Ukraine from three directions, according to military analysts: the north, east and south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Weighs Whether States May Defend a Trump Immigration Policy
description: After the Biden administration abandoned the policy, which tightened the “public charge” rule for green card applicants, Republican-led states sought to intervene.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a tangled dispute over whether Republican-led states may step in to defend a Trump-era immigration policy that the Biden administration has abandoned. The policy, a revision of the “public charge” rule, imposed a new wealth test on applicants for green cards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Ana Ley
title: Subway Platform Barriers Will Be Tested at 3 N.Y.C. Stations
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which had resisted calls to add platform barriers, will begin a pilot program amid outcry over safety in the transit system.
content: For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had resisted calls to install the platform barriers that are used in subway systems around the globe to block access to tracks, citing the “special complexities” of bringing such technology to a century-old system not designed for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Climate Fears on Back Burner as Fuel Costs Soar and Russia Crisis Deepens
description: Energy security has gained prominence while the conflict in Ukraine raises concerns over the possible interruption in the supply of oil and natural gas.
content: It was only three months ago that world leaders met at the Glasgow climate summit and made ambitious pledges to reduce fossil fuel use. The perils of a warming planet are no less calamitous now, but the debate about the critically important transition to renewable energy has taken a back seat to energy security as Russia — Europe’s largest energy supplier — threatens to start a major confrontation with the West over Ukraine while oil prices are climbing toward $100 a barrel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 23, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 23, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about President Biden’s efforts to prevent armed conflict in Ukraine misstated the location where the President’s Daily Brief is normally held. It is in the Oval Office, not the Situation Room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The Met Opera’s New Season: What We Want to See
description: After a long streak without canceled performances that continued through the Omicron surge, the company announced ambitious plans for 2022-23.
content: After a long-awaited return to the stage last fall, and a remarkable streak without canceled performances that continued through the Omicron surge, the Metropolitan Opera announced on Wednesday a new season that it hopes will help bring audiences back in force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William P. Davis
title: The White House says releasing more oil from reserves is ‘on the table.’
description: America’s emergency stockpile was tapped in November, seemingly to little effect.
content: The United States is prepared to release oil from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve as the Russia-Ukraine crisis helps drive up prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: No Justification for a Brazen Invasion
description: The magnitude of Mr. Putin’s gambit in Ukraine is staggering.
content: Explosions were reported in cities across Ukraine early Thursday morning after President Vladimir Putin of Russia vowed in a speech to “demilitarize” the neighboring nation, and any hope for a peaceful resolution to the crisis appeared all but snuffed out. On Wednesday, Ukraine declared a 30-day state of emergency, called up military reserves and warned its citizens to leave Russia. The European Union announced it was preparing to handle a large influx of refugees uprooted by war. Financial markets are bracing for the turmoil that a land war and sanctions could unleash across the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Word by Word and Between the Lines: A Close Look at Putin’s Speech
description: In an impassioned address about Ukraine, Russia’s leader laid bare grievances old and new. We took at look at what it might mean.
content: Follow our live coverage on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Russia’s moves in Ukraine prompt calls to move the Champions League final out of St. Petersburg.
description: The most vocal opposition has come from Britain, which could supply one or both of the final’s participants.
content: Russia’s aggression in Ukraine has exposed fissures in European soccer that are threatening multimillion-dollar sponsorship agreements and have led to calls to move the biggest game on this season’s calendar, the Champions League final, out of its scheduled host city, St. Petersburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Interviews 3 Supreme Court Candidates as His Search Narrows
description: The White House says the president is on track to decide on a nominee to fill the seat vacated by Justice Stephen G. Breyer by the end of February.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has interviewed at least three candidates for his Supreme Court nomination, a signal that he intends to fulfill his promise that he would choose a nominee by the end of the month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The U.S. is preparing a ban on American technology exports to Russia.
description: The Biden administration warned on Wednesday of additional measures it is preparing in the event Russia escalates an armed conflict in Ukraine, signaling that it is ready to impose a ban on exports of American technology that are vital to the Russian economy.
content: The Biden administration warned on Wednesday of additional measures it is preparing in the event Russia escalates an armed conflict in Ukraine, signaling that it is ready to impose a ban on exports of American technology that are vital to the Russian economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Getting Hitched? Good Luck Finding Food, Photographers and Even Venues
description: Some of this year’s betrothed are setting wedding dates to accommodate vendors, relying on the kindness of friends and even resorting to bribes.
content: Read more about the 2022 wedding boom in our ongoing Year of the Wedding series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iraj Pezeshkzad, Author of Classic Iranian Novel, Dies at 94
description: The satirical “My Uncle Napoleon” became a cultural touchstone that held up a mirror to his country, before the 1979 revolution sent the author into exile in Paris.
content: Iraj Pezeshkzad, a prominent Iranian writer and satirist who became a cultural figure after his blockbuster novel, “My Uncle Napoleon,” captured the imaginations of generations of Iranians, died on Jan. 12 in Los Angeles. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: The Potentially Grim Fate of a Ukrainian Town Called ‘Happiness’
description: If Russia invades, military analysts say, the border settlement’s Russian-sympathizing citizenry and its prize power plant make it a likely starting point.
content: SHCHASTYA, Ukraine — A drunk sat on a bench, swaying. A few older women, bundled against a biting wind, scurried from a grocery store, clutching plastic bags. Otherwise, the streets of Shchastya were deserted, while the thud of mortar and artillery fire reverberated through town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Law & Order’ Review: Leaving Out the Best Parts
description: The show’s first episode in 12 years has the intro, the music, the dun-dun, and a couple of the old stars. But it’s missing the things that made the series essential.
content: An unsuspecting pair of New Yorkers walk past Rockefeller Center and see something alarming under an NBC sign. It’s the body of a television show, barely breathing. The first officer on the scene tells the detectives it’s that famous old series with the funny noise, and it was trying for a comeback. Lennie Briscoe eyes the stiff and declares, “Nothing to see here.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Residents Facing Hard Choice as Fighting Nears: Stay or Flee
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 23, 2022.
content: “It’s the fourth or fifth incoming. Oh, dear mother, what should I do? It’s coming in. A lot is coming in.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Republican Candidates Split Over Ukraine-Russia Crisis
description: In Ohio, two Republicans running for Senate have taken sharply different positions, offering a clear view of the party’s rift over foreign policy.
content: You won’t find a clearer distillation of the Republican Party’s divide on foreign policy than the sparring that broke out this weekend in Ohio over Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: How Markets Are Thinking About the Ukraine Battle Lines
description: Investors are assessing the consequences of the intensifying conflict, from sanctions to shortages and price surges.
content: The markets have been unsettled for many reasons this year, but the escalating conflict between Ukraine and Russia pushed them past a symbolic milestone yesterday. The S&P 500 slipped into a so-called correction, defined as a decline of least 10 percent from the most recent high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy says it will end its pandemic state of emergency on March 31.
description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi said on Wednesday that the situation in Italy had improved enough to allow the emergency declaration to lapse after more than two years.
content: Italy will allow its coronavirus-related state of emergency to expire on March 31, Prime Minister Mario Draghi said on Wednesday, because the success of the vaccine campaign had greatly improved the situation in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘“Why Was I Born a Girl?” An Afghan Poem Inspires U.S. Students’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how a Zoom connection between high schoolers in Afghanistan and San Diego opened a window for mutual support.
content: Featured Article: “‘Why Was I Born a Girl?’ An Afghan Poem Inspires U.S. Students” by David Zucchino with photographs by Jim Huylebroek
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Four Dead in Helicopter Crash at U.S. Naval Facility in Hawaii
description: The helicopter was participating in a training operation when it “just went down,” killing everyone on board.
content: A helicopter operated by a military contractor crashed during a training mission in Hawaii on Tuesday, killing all four people on board, the U.S. Navy said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: IMAX Looks Beyond Movies to Live Events
description: To combat the decline of theatergoing, the large-format cinema company will show events like concerts, stand-up comedy and e-sports tournaments.
content: As Kanye West thundered through “Black Skinhead” at the Los Angeles Coliseum in December as part of a benefit concert, young fans in the front row threw their bodies around in wild abandon. Others pumped their fists in the air and shouted along to the lyrics: “Pardon, I’m getting my scream on!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘The Same’ Review: Do You See What I See?
description: Enda Walsh’s play, which had its U.S. premiere at the Irish Arts Center, stars two sisters who play different versions of the same character.
content: Imagine that on one otherwise normal day, while going about your normal activities, you encounter someone who looks uncannily familiar — it’s you. Does the discovery cause you discomfort or give you relief? Are you met with assurance or fear?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: A Pianist Explores Mozart the Late Bloomer
description: Víkingur Ólafsson made his Carnegie Hall debut with a hypnotically unfurling program based on his recent album “Mozart and Contemporaries.”
content: Mozart, the pianist Víkingur Ólafsson deadpanned from the stage at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening, was a “late bloomer.” The audience chuckled at the thought of one of history’s great child prodigies, dead at 35, taking a long time to find his gifts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkey, still recovering from pandemic lockdowns, is shocked by soaring electricity bills.
description: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s economy was already in recession before the pandemic hit, and because it relies heavily on tourism and the hospitality industry, the months of lockdown have badly hurt many businesses and robbed many residents of income. Now the country is grappling with runaway inflation.
content: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s economy was already in recession before the pandemic hit, and because it relies heavily on tourism and the hospitality industry, the months of lockdown have badly hurt many businesses and robbed many residents of income. Now the country is grappling with runaway inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
title: Putin Insulated Russia’s Economy. Will Biden’s Sanctions Hold Him Back in Ukraine?
description: President Vladimir V. Putin has learned from earlier U.S.-led sanctions, and his allies could benefit from a more isolated Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration imposed sanctions on Russia for invading Ukraine in 2014, American officials were hopeful they would deter President Vladimir V. Putin from further aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: U.N. leader deepens criticism of Russia over Ukraine crisis.
description: António Guterres said Ukraine’s sovereign territory had been violated, and he rejected Vladimir Putin’s description of Russian troops as peacekeepers.
content: The leader of the United Nations deepened his criticism of Russia on Tuesday over its actions in Ukraine, not only describing them as a violation of Ukrainian sovereignty but disparaging the Kremlin’s descriptions of its troops as peacekeepers. He called the crisis a test of the global organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Stellantis reports a big profit even as a chip shortage hurt production.
description: The automaker, which owns Jeep, Ram and Peugeot, said its profit had more than doubled, thanks to higher prices and cost-cutting measures that outweighed the semiconductor shortage.
content: The automaker Stellantis said its profit more than doubled in 2021 to 13.3 billion euros, a result of cost savings and higher car prices that more than offset disruptions to production and sales caused by the global shortage of computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: With Inflation High, People Are Talking About Price Controls. Is That a Terrible Idea?
description: The United States hasn’t used them since Nixon’s presidency.
content: On April 9, 1946, The New York Times published a letter to the editor that would strike most people today as strange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: The Beef Patty Is Jamaica in the Palm of Your Hand
description: One of our new Eat columnists, Bryan Washington, on a quintessentially Jamaican food that’s now found all over the world.
content: A Jamaican beef patty is an island’s history in the palm of your hand. All of its spices, triumphs, fluctuations and migrations. They’re minced. Lathered. Chewed between the flakiest of pastry crusts. The patty is a vehicle for deliciousness and a simulacrum of the nation’s rhythms, and your patty could be a late breakfast, or an early lunch, or a boozy midnight snack. You might eat yours in a paper bag. You could order four under the streetlights of a curbside pop-up. Or maybe, if you’re lucky, it’s simply pulled from your oven, tossed directly from your baking pan into the loaf of coco bread on your counter. For a moment, your only problem in the world is wishing you had three or four more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Anton Troianovski, Austin Ramzy, Valerie Hopkins and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Global leaders send a message with coordinated penalties.
description: WASHINGTON — Russia faced mounting pressure and economic sanctions over the Ukraine crisis on Wednesday as the United States and allies coordinated punishments and denounced the beginning of an “invasion of Ukraine.”
content: WASHINGTON — Russia faced mounting pressure and economic sanctions over the Ukraine crisis on Wednesday as the United States and allies coordinated punishments and denounced the beginning of an “invasion of Ukraine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Levin
title: Allendale, N.J.: A Low-Profile, Walkable Suburb, 25 Miles From Midtown
description: The manicured Bergen County borough is ‘under the radar,’ but residents prefer it that way.
content: Lesley and Chris Jones see a bit of North Ferriby, the English village where they used to live, in Allendale, the manicured New Jersey suburb where they put down roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Luke Broadwater
title: Ivanka Trump in Talks With Jan. 6 Panel About Being Interviewed
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s eldest daughter has yet to commit to appearing, but investigators regard her as an important witness to what he was doing and saying during the riot.
content: WASHINGTON — Ivanka Trump, former President Donald J. Trump’s eldest daughter who served as one of his senior advisers, is in talks with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol about the possibility of sitting for an interview with the panel, according to two people familiar with the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Officer Accused of Recklessly Firing in Breonna Taylor Raid Goes on Trial
description: Brett Hankison, a former Louisville police detective, is facing three charges of wanton endangerment after the authorities said he fired “blindly” into Ms. Taylor’s apartment.
content: The only trial to emerge from the nighttime police raid that killed Breonna Taylor began on Wednesday, but the case centers not on an officer who shot her, but rather on a former police detective accused of recklessly endangering her neighbors with a hail of bullets that inadvertently hit their apartment in Louisville, Ky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Tolek Magdziarz
title: Poland will lift most remaining restrictions on March 1.
description: The move is a turnaround for the Eastern European nation, which was among a handful of countries in the region that were hit especially hard by earlier variants.
content: Poland will lift most of its remaining coronavirus restrictions on March 1, but it will keep in place a mask mandate for public transportation and indoor venues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
title: White House Prepares Curbs on Russia’s Access to U.S. Technology
description: Biden administration officials have warned Russia that it could face further restrictions on technology that is critical to its economy and military.
content: The Biden administration warned on Wednesday that it had prepared additional measures aimed at cutting off Russia from advanced technology critical to its economy and military in the event of further aggression by President Vladimir V. Putin toward Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: A Comeback for Physical Stores
description: The future does not necessarily arrive in a straight line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Cytron-Walker
title: My Synagogue Was Attacked, but I Will Never Stop Welcoming the Stranger
description: At the core of most ethical traditions is a command to open our doors, not to close them.
content: Some teachings, such as, “Love your neighbor” or, “Care for your community,” are shared by almost every religious or ethical practice. From an evolutionary standpoint, that makes sense: In the long run, the group does better than the individual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
title: Russian Mercenaries Have Covertly Entered Separatist Enclaves in Ukraine
description: Two senior European security officials say that the paramilitary fighters are inside the rebel territories of Ukraine to lay the groundwork for war.
content: Follow the latest news on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering Betty Davis, a Futuristic Funk Force
description: A conversation about her unique music, her short career and the path that led to her rediscovery.
content: The three albums Betty Davis released in the 1970s — “Betty Davis” in 1973, “They Say I’m Different” in 1974 and “Nasty Gal” in 1975 — were not huge commercial successes, but they were profoundly advanced statements of funk futurism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Will Russia invade Ukraine?
description: The Pentagon says troops are in place to attack.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine Crisis Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict. I’m your host, Carole Landry. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Maternal Deaths Rose During the First Year of the Pandemic
description: Deaths during pregnancy and the first six weeks after childbirth increased, especially for Black and Hispanic women, according to a new report.
content: The number of women in the United States who died during pregnancy or shortly after giving birth increased sharply during the first year of the coronavirus pandemic, according to a new study, an increase that health officials attribute partly to Covid and pandemic-related disruptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: New Zealand Protest, an Echo of Canada’s, Digs In and Turns Ugly
description: An occupation in the capital demonstrates the dangerous influence that American disinformation is having on otherwise stable democracies.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — The antigovernment protests that jolted Canada have been quashed. But 9,000 miles away, in the capital of another Western democracy largely unaccustomed to violent tears in the social fabric, an occupation on the grounds of Parliament has entrenched itself and turned increasingly ominous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: A class-action lawsuit claims CareCube charged New Yorkers for virus tests they thought were free.
description: Two Bronx residents are seeking more than $10 million in damages,  claiming the company overcharged them.
content: A Brooklyn-based physicians group is facing a class-action lawsuit accusing it of charging hundreds of dollars for coronavirus tests to New Yorkers who thought they were getting them for free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Restoring ‘The Godfather’ to Its Original (Still Dark) Glory
description: Francis Ford Coppola discusses a repaired 50th-anniversary edition of his classic, one that aims to be as vivid — and shadowy — as it was in 1972.
content: After 50 years, Francis Ford Coppola still isn’t finished with “The Godfather” — and it isn’t finished with him, either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: A Powerful New Vaccine
description: The new vaccine from Sanofi and GSK achieved 100 percent efficacy against severe disease.
content: The makers of a new coronavirus vaccine announced results from their clinical trials today — and they are very promising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Goldwert
title: Why We Dream About Past Loves
description: And what the dreams can teach us about our own yearnings, then and now.
content: If you’ve slept, perchance you have dreamed about an ex and woken up wondering, “What was that all about?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: The Doctor Giving DeSantis’s Pandemic Policies a Seal of Approval
description: Dr. Joseph Ladapo, Florida’s new surgeon general, has vowed to “completely reject fear” in managing the pandemic.
content: MIAMI — Dr. Joseph A. Ladapo has come out strongly against mask mandates and lockdowns, only supports vaccination campaigns if the shots are voluntary and will not say whether he himself has been vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: The Complex Truth About American Patriotism
description: Who gets to be called a patriot in America?
content: An American flag, football, the national anthem, “Make America Great Again” — all of these can be symbols of American patriotism, but to whom? In 2022 the notion of being a patriot is complex, to say the least, and in a divided nation one might ask: Who gets to be called a patriot, and what does patriotism really mean in America?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Emile Ducke
title: On Eve of War, No Exodus From Ukraine, Only Anxiety and Disbelief
description: When Russian troops moved into eastern Ukraine, some began to travel westward, filled with doubt about the future but saying they planned — or hoped — to return.
content: UKRAINIAN RAILWAYS TRAIN 749 — We boarded the train heading for Lviv, in the northwest corner of Ukraine, near the Polish border and the NATO front lines, expecting to find it crowded with people fleeing ahead of a Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: How Colombian Feminists Decriminalized Abortion: With Help From Their Neighbors
description: As the United States faces growing restrictions on abortion, activists in Latin America are increasingly relying on one another to knock down barriers in the region.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Decades of grass roots organizing, with meetings in living rooms and in the streets, online and across borders, have produced a tectonic shift on abortion in Latin America, a historically conservative region where access to the procedure has long been severely limited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
description: This month’s nonfiction picks include a film on suburban surveillance, a deep dive into movie sound and an Oscar-nominated exploration of teens on the margins.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Sea Ice Around Antarctica Reaches a Record Low
description: The drop surprised scientists, and may help them understand more about climate change affecting Antarctica and its waters.
content: Sea ice around Antarctica has reached a record low in four decades of observations, a new analysis of satellite images shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Austin Mitchell, Michael Simon Johnson, Mooj Zadie, M.J. Davis Lin, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: ‘A Knife to the Throat’: Putin’s Logic for Invading Ukraine
description: An address by the Russian president on Monday revealed some of the thinking behind the aggression and hinted at his wider intentions.
content: At 10 p.m. in Moscow on Monday, Russian state television interrupted its regular programming to air an address from President Vladimir V. Putin about the Ukraine crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: North Carolina Court Imposes New District Map, Eliminating G.O.P. Edge
description: The map appears to split the state’s 14 congressional districts roughly equally between Republicans and Democrats, with two seats seen as tossups.
content: WASHINGTON — A North Carolina court rejected a Republican-drawn map of the state’s 14 congressional districts on Wednesday and substituted its own version, the second time in less than two weeks that a court in the state has invalidated a Republican House map as unconstitutionally partisan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos and Maria Cramer
title: Man Charged With Murder in Shooting at Protest in Portland
description: A 60-year-old woman was killed and five others, including the suspect, were shot during a confrontation near the man’s house, the authorities said.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — A 43-year-old Portland man was charged with murder on Tuesday in a shooting during a weekend protest against police killings in which a woman was killed and five others including the suspect were wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in Spain: A Restored Two-Bedroom in Central Barcelona
description: New rent-control laws and the pandemic downturn have made the Catalonian capital a tougher sell for investors than in years past.
content: This two-bedroom apartment, in the Sant Antoni neighborhood of Barcelona, has an updated interior brightened by multiple outdoor spaces, including a 430-square-foot terrace — a rarity in the center of the city — with zones dedicated to dining, sunbathing and doing laundry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: 16-Year-Old Chess Prodigy Defeats World Champion Magnus Carlsen
description: While it did not affect the reigning champion’s title, Rameshbabu Praggnanandhaa of India defeated Carlsen in the middle of the night during a rapid online tournament, stunning the chess world.
content: After Rameshbabu Praggnanandhaa, 16, pulled off a stunning win in an elite rapid chess tournament from his computer in India on Monday, there were no hands of fellow competitors to shake or snapping cameras to capture the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: Dirtbag Glamour Is Ascendant Once More
description: Rejecting conventional ideals of good taste in favor of grit and grime, fashion’s new mood continues a long tradition.
content: RECENTLY, WITHOUT FANFARE or warning, the friends and collaborators Pete Davidson and Colson Baker (better known by his rap pseudonym, Machine Gun Kelly) dropped their pants and went live on the Calvin Klein Instagram account in a sendup of the label’s famous underwear commercials. Maintaining a running gag that they had not, in fact, been hired as models for the brand (they had), they joked about fluffing up “the boys” and poured popcorn into each other’s mouths. Something felt off as the 28-year-old “Saturday Night Live” star and the 31-year-old actor and musician flopped around on an immaculate white couch. It wasn’t just that two straight men, famous for dating even more famous women, were baiting their queer followers by mock flirting with each other in various states of undress, although they were. It was that they looked, uncharacteristically, as clean as the white boxer briefs they’d been paid to wear. Pretending to imagine their power as poster boys, Davidson said, “We could have gotten all the dirty people to buy underwear. … Dirty, trash — like our fans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: 1MDB Trial Will Take a Break So the Defense Can Study New Documents
description: Prosecutors in a case involving a former Goldman Sachs executive and a Malaysian fund found 15,000 emails and other documents they need to turn over.
content: The bribery and money-laundering trial of a former Goldman Sachs executive was thrown into turmoil after federal prosecutors — for the second time in a little over a week — said the government had failed to promptly turn over thousands of pages of emails and other personal documents belonging to a key witness for the prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A global response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: The U.S. and its allies swiftly imposed economic sanctions on Russia for what President Biden denounced as the beginning of an “invasion of Ukraine.” Western officials have confirmed that Russian forces have crossed the Ukrainian border into two separatist enclaves in eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Can Sanctions Work?
description: Yes, but they often don’t.
content: Eight years ago, after Russia annexed Ukraine’s Crimean Peninsula, the U.S. and its allies harshly condemned the invasion and imposed economic sanctions on Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: New Guides, New Paths: Tour Companies Aim to Boost Diversity
description: After the global reckoning over race in 2020, some group-tour providers made a pledge to improve equity through training, mentoring and funding for minority guides. Those programs are now up and running.
content: In late 2020, Leon Burnette, an independent tour director and civil rights historian, received a phone call from the director of a global travel company, asking him to recommend Black tour guides for a new tour being created along the United States Civil Rights Trail, which snakes from Kansas to Washington, D.C. But there was a problem: Mr. Burnette hardly knew any.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Do You Collect?
description: Coins are becoming popular among young people. Do you have a passion for collecting things?
content: Do you like collecting? Have you ever collected things like sneakers, dolls, comic books or stamps?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Fed Up With Google, Conspiracy Theorists Turn to DuckDuckGo
description: The embrace by some conservative influencers and conspiracy theorists is part of a broader effort to shift people away from Big Tech.
content: On an episode of Joe Rogan’s popular podcast last year, he turned to a topic that has gripped right-wing communities and other Americans who feel skeptical about the pandemic: search engines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: ‘A Time of Worries’: New York City’s Ukrainians Are Anxious and Afraid
description: Their families back home refuse to leave. So they fret, connected like never before, but unable to change events.
content: When the first news reports of Russian troop movements began to appear in the Ukrainian media a few months ago, Vironika Giacchi, who manages a jewelry store in Manhattan, enrolled in a first aid class near her home in Staten Island. If Russia mounts a full-scale invasion, she said, she will return to Ukraine and volunteer as a nurse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Melting Man
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Hearing on Henry Darger Estate Dispute Is Postponed
description: Distant relatives are seeking to gain control of the outsider artist’s estate from a former landlord, who says that Darger gave the art and literary works he created to her husband.
content: A hearing to help determine who has the rights to the estate of the janitor-turned-artist Henry Darger was postponed on Wednesday for procedural reasons in an Illinois probate court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Columbia Psychiatry Chair Suspended After Tweet About Dark-Skinned Model
description: The post from Jeffrey Lieberman, which described the model as possibly a “freak of nature,” drew negative attention from medical professionals.
content: The chair of the Columbia University Department of Psychiatry was suspended on Wednesday, “effective immediately,” after referring to a dark-skinned model as possibly a “freak of nature” on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $550,000 Homes in Texas, Georgia and Massachusetts
description: A renovated 1951 house in Houston, a two-bedroom condominium in Atlanta and a 1791 home in Halifax.
content: This house is in North Macgregor Oaks, a neighborhood less than two miles from Hermann Park, which has a Japanese garden, an outdoor theater and a zoo. Some of the city’s most popular museums, including the Houston Museum of Natural Science and the Museum of Fine Arts, are also nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Moscow says separatist allies requested its help, and the U.S. says a Russian attack on Ukraine could be imminent.
description: WASHINGTON — In its most dire assessment yet, the Pentagon said on Wednesday that 80 percent of the 190,000 Russian troops and separatist forces in or near Ukraine are now in combat-ready positions, and that a full-scale military assault is most likely imminent.
content: WASHINGTON — In its most dire assessment yet, the Pentagon said on Wednesday that 80 percent of the 190,000 Russian troops and separatist forces in or near Ukraine are now in combat-ready positions, and that a full-scale military assault is most likely imminent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Get Cracking!
description: Rose Conlon brings her first New York Times Crossword into the world.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Rose Conlon, who is making her New York Times Crossword debut today (the 15th debut of 2022).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: European Sanctions Target Putin’s Inner Circle
description: The measures, coinciding with new U.S. moves, were designed to hurt individuals but not average Russians. But more will follow if Russia fully invades Ukraine.
content: BRUSSELS — The list included some of the Kremlin’s highest ranking officials, the top Russian military leadership, senior bank executives, a prominent news anchor, the head of a global television network and a Russian businessman with links to a mercenary group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
title: Russia Is Sowing Conflict in Ukraine. What Does That Mean for the U.S. Economy?
description: A Russian invasion of Ukraine could push up oil and food prices globally at a time of already-high inflation. In the U.S., it will drive up uncertainty.
content: Russia’s threatened invasion of Ukraine could have economic repercussions globally and in the United States, ramping up uncertainty, roiling commodity markets and potentially pushing up inflation as gas and food prices rise around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: The Strange Connection Between Mono and M.S.
description: New research proves a virus — one that almost all of us have — “causes” multiple sclerosis.
content: Denis Burkitt, an Irish surgeon, traveled to Africa during World War II as a member of the Royal Army Medical Corps, and afterward he settled in Uganda to practice medicine. There he observed that a surprising number of children developed strange jaw tumors, a cancer that would come to be known as Burkitt lymphoma. Eventually, Burkitt sent samples of the tumor cells to Middlesex Hospital Medical School in London, where Michael Anthony Epstein, a pathologist, and his colleagues Yvonne Barr and Bert Achong examined them through an electron microscope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum
title: Former N.Y.P.D. Union Head Charged in Fraud Case
description: Edward D. Mullins, the combative longtime leader of the Sergeants Benevolent Association, quit his union job and retired from the Police Department last year amid scandal.
content: The former president of a powerful New York City Police union has been charged with defrauding the union of hundreds of thousands of dollars by filing false and inflated expense reports for bills that were purportedly for union business but in fact were not, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: Married to a Deal Breaker
description: Could you fall in love with someone who can’t quit the thing you hate?
content: What are your dating non-negotiables? For Hyla Sabesin Finn, it was smoking — or so she thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Companies in the E.U. could be held liable for violations along their supply chain.
description: Under the legislation, known as a due diligence law, businesses would need to establish regulations to detect, prevent and mitigate breaches of human rights.
content: Large companies operating in the European Union could be held responsible for environmental violations or human rights abuses committed by businesses in their supply chains under a law proposed on Wednesday by the European Commission, the bloc’s administrative arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Husband of Slain Cinematographer Was ‘Just So Angry’ at Alec Baldwin
description: Matthew Hutchins, the widower of Halyna Hutchins, says in an upcoming “Today” show interview that it was “absurd” for Mr. Baldwin to deny responsibility in the fatal shooting.
content: The widower of Halyna Hutchins, the cinematographer killed by Alec Baldwin on the “Rust” film set in New Mexico last year, said in an upcoming television interview that he was angry with the actor for denying responsibility in the fatal shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Alan Feuer
title: A Truck Caravan With Far-Right Links Heads to Washington, D.C.
description: Many backers of the caravan, planned as an American version of the past month’s chaotic Canadian protest, have connections to the violent attack on the Capitol in January 2021.
content: ADELANTO, Calif. — Though it was billed as a grass-roots, nonpartisan event intended to oppose government Covid-19 mandates, a trucker demonstration that left California for Washington, D.C., on Wednesday appeared to be tightly aligned with far-right organizations and activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Revisiting the California Soundtrack
description: The latest update to our ever-evolving playlist that tries to capture the spirit of the Golden State.
content: Today I’m back with a new edition of the California Soundtrack, our ever-evolving project that tries to capture the spirit of the Golden State through music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Ireland ends mask mandates in most places and social distancing in schools.
description: Ireland will end social distancing in schools and lift its mask requirement “in all settings where currently regulated,” officials announced on Tuesday. Public health officials will still recommend the use of masks on public transportation and in health care settings.
content: Ireland will end social distancing in schools and lift its mask requirement “in all settings where currently regulated,” officials announced on Tuesday. Public health officials will still recommend the use of masks on public transportation and in health care settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauna Farnell
title: At 65 and Legally Blind, ‘Sister Shred’ Has Never Met a Slope She Wouldn’t Ride
description: Kris Nordberg still loves rolling through rock gardens and shredding powder on her ski bike — sometimes, in a nun costume.
content: Even when Sister Shred isn’t donning a nun Halloween costume, she doesn’t fit the typical mold of a daredevil dropping off boulders on a mountain bike or carving steep slopes and deep powder on a ski bike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: F.D.A. Grants the First Condom Approval for Anal Sex
description: Though public health experts have long advised the use of condoms for anal sex to protect against H.I.V. and other infections, regulators did not have enough data to allow marketing for that use.
content: For the first time, U.S. regulators have officially authorized a condom to be used for anal sex, not just vaginal sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: China criticizes sanctions against Russia as ineffective and warns of wider damage.
description: Beijing said the penalties could hurt average people and its own interests.
content: China on Wednesday criticized the expansion of economic sanctions against Russia, saying that they were unlikely to solve the Ukraine crisis and that they had the potential to harm average people as well as the interests of Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Fax Machines and Popcorn Spills: The Rocky Road to N.B.A. Coaching
description: Wes Unseld Jr. had done almost everything possible to prepare to be a head coach, from interning to selling tickets. But, he said, you can’t fully understand the job “until you’re in it.”
content: Wes Unseld Jr. still has some of the reports he filed as a young scout for the Washington Wizards in the late 1990s. When he looks at them now, he said, they appear so basic. He still has no idea why Mike Brown, one of the team’s assistants at the time, was so encouraging and supportive of his work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: More Trouble for a Troubled Market
description: Whether you call it a correction or a panic attack, a stock market that was already becoming shaky has been roiled by Russia’s hostilities toward Ukraine.
content: The U.S. stock market has been stumbling since the beginning of the year. Now, Russia’s escalating conflict with Ukraine is adding considerably to the market’s problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Black Artists Pioneered Electronic Music. This Festival Celebrates Them.
description: The founder of the Dweller festival, now in its third year in New York, started the event to center Black D.J.s and producers, “and imagine what we want.”
content: Frankie Decaiza Hutchinson had been awake since 5 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. to End Trump-Era Initiative to Deter Chinese Threats
description: The agency will instead introduce a broader strategy meant to address threats from a slate of hostile nations.
content: ARLINGTON, Va. — The Justice Department said on Wednesday that it was ending a contentious Trump-era effort to fight Chinese national security threats that critics said unfairly targeted professors of Asian descent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: New York Now Leads Nation in Mobile Sports Betting
description: Since the state opened online betting in early January, it has become the biggest bookmaking market, surpassing Nevada and New Jersey.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at New York State’s surge in the newly legalized world of online sports betting (and how bettors used ‘Twosday’ to play the numbers). Also, Mayor Eric Adams is criticized for some appointments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: Can a Reality TV Show Sell You on a $2,298 E-Bike?
description: Welcome to “Bike Hunters,” a Dutch YouTube series that promises to recover stolen e-bikes — but really makes you want one of your own.
content: We’re at the scene of the crime. Stockholm, Sweden. Two men — Ludo and Daniel — stand by a portable sauna mounted on a trailer bed. “So, you were in here?” Daniel says, pointing forcefully. “And they just took it from you?” Ludo confirms. “Oh, my God,” Daniel says, turning to the camera in the manner of someone practiced at generating on-the-scene narration for viewers at home: “Crazy story. You go to the sauna. You’re relaxing inside. And the next thing you know, your bike, which is parked next to you, just gets stolen. Double-locked, they carried it away.” He’s visibly peeved: This can’t stand. “Nah. Let’s find this bike.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: When It Comes to Wordle Strategies, It’s Personal
description: Aficionados of the deceptively simple word game, including Monica Lewinsky and J. Smith-Cameron, weigh in with their opening gambits.
content: I’m usually an ADIEU person, but to mix it up I sometimes start with CHAOS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: Brunello Cucinelli Keeps Chickens, and Many Books, at His 17th-Century Italian Villa
description: The fashion designer, a lover of history, philosophy and country life, has made his home in the Umbrian hamlet of Solomeo.
content: The fashion designer Brunello Cucinelli grew up in an ancient stone farmhouse outside the town of Castel Rigone in Umbria, Italy. It didn’t have electricity or running water and, as it was shared among 13 members of the extended Cucinelli family, could feel a bit crowded. Still, “it’s a house that is beautiful to me,” says Cucinelli, 68, who has fond memories of playing with his siblings and cousins in the kitchen’s cavernous fireplace, and of slipping downstairs to the cow stables before school to steal milk directly from the source.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Is Your Experience With Feeding Our Future?
description: We’re interested in learning more about the Minnesota-based nonprofit Feeding Our Future, which is being investigated by the F.B.I. for possible fraud.
content: David Fahrenthold, a reporter for The New York Times, is in Minnesota this week, reporting on the F.B.I.’s investigation into possible fraud involving government programs meant to feed hungry children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: John Szeles, Who Mixed Jokes With Gore as the Amazing Johnathan, Dies at 63
description: Mr. Szeles, who performed steadily in Las Vegas, smoothly incorporated vaudevillian jokes and bloody magic tricks into his act.
content: John Edward Szeles, the comedian and magician who combined jokes with ersatz gore in his stage persona as the Amazing Johnathan, died on Tuesday at his home in Henderson, Nev., outside Las Vegas. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Joe Tom Easley, Gay Rights Activist Whose Marriage Made The Times, Dies at 81
description: Mr. Easley took a leading role in the campaign against “don’t ask, don’t tell,” the Clinton-era policy that required gay service members to hide their sexual orientation.
content: Joe Tom Easley, the gay rights activist and lawyer who worked to repeal the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy and whose 2003 wedding was among the first same-sex unions announced in The New York Times, died on Feb. 13 at a hospital in Miami Beach. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The National Guard Deploys to Classrooms
description: New Mexico recruited its state militia to keep schools open.
content: Today: Staff sergeants lead classrooms, the Biden administration moves to end a policy that targeted Chinese researchers and after a pandemic hiatus, Modern Love is back with its college essay contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Why Do I Wake Up With a Headache?
description: And is there anything I can do to find relief?
content: Q: I often get headaches in the morning. They improve when I get up and have coffee, but I can’t seem to figure out how to prevent them. I have tried various pillows and sleeping positions. What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: For Some N.B.A. Prospects, a Taste of the Big Time
description: Members of a developmental team, the N.B.A. G League Ignite, some still in their teens, participated in the N.B.A.’s All-Star Weekend.
content: Amauri Hardy sat in the stands during the N.B.A.’s All-Star Weekend in Cleveland, watching his little brother, Jaden, on the court with the best young players in the league. He thought about the work Jaden had put into his game and the guts he showed in leaving home as a teenager to follow a nontraditional path into professional basketball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Albright
title: Putin Is Making a Historic Mistake
description: Instead of paving Russia’s path to greatness, invading Ukraine would ensure Mr. Putin’s infamy.
content: In early 2000, I became the first senior U.S. official to meet with Vladimir Putin in his new capacity as acting president of Russia. We in the Clinton administration did not know much about him at the time — just that he had started his career in the K.G.B. I hoped the meeting would help me take the measure of the man and assess what his sudden elevation might mean for U.S.-Russia relations, which had deteriorated amid the war in Chechnya. Sitting across a small table from him in the Kremlin, I was immediately struck by the contrast between Mr. Putin and his bombastic predecessor, Boris Yeltsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘The Man From the Future’ Recounts the Life of a Restless Genius
description: In his new book, Ananyo Bhattacharya writes about John von Neumann, who played an essential role in the development of quantum mechanics, computing and the atom bomb.
content: The mathematician John von Neumann was an undeniable genius whose many accomplishments included an essential role in the development of quantum mechanics, computing and the atom bomb. As the co-author of one of the first textbooks on game theory, he took a coolly analytical approach to a range of situations that included bluffing in poker and the prospect of nuclear annihilation. Still, von Neumann didn’t let his deep understanding of physics and rational utility get in the way of something else that was clearly very important to him: a love of driving, along with what seemed to be a cheerful commitment to being terrible at it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller
title: Finding ‘Funny Girl.’ Finally.
description: After nearly six decades and many false starts, the musical is returning to Broadway, with Beanie Feldstein taking on the role that made Barbra Streisand a star.
content: Michael Mayer had one eye on his “Funny Girl” cast and one eye on his phone. The cast was rehearsing “His Love Makes Me Beautiful,” a comic song from the musical’s first act. And the phone was humming with texts from Harvey Fierstein, on board to fine-tune the script, under Mayer’s direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Riffs on Joe Biden’s Sanctions Against Russia
description: Colbert said Putin sought to keep the peace, and imitated Russia’s president: “I keep this piece of Ukraine. I keep that piece of Ukraine. I keep all the pieces of Ukraine.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Sarah Palin will seek a new trial after her unsuccessful suit against The Times.
description: Lawyers have told a federal judge that they will file several motions scrutinizing the timing of his announcement that he intended to dismiss the case for lack of evidence.
content: Lawyers representing Sarah Palin in her unsuccessful defamation lawsuit against The New York Times have told a federal judge that they plan to ask for a new trial and will file several other motions seeking to scrutinize the timing of his announcement that he intended to dismiss the case for lack of evidence if a verdict favored Ms. Palin. His statement arrived while the jury was still deliberating last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Donald Trump’s Truth Social is off to a glitchy start.
description: The official debut of the former president’s social media platform on Monday was marred by error messages and a long waiting list for people who had signed up for access.
content: The rollout of Truth Social, former President Donald J. Trump’s social media alternative to Twitter, has gotten off to a slow start.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Climate Newsletter Is Getting Even Better
description: Starting on Tuesday, Climate Forward will be coming out twice a week. Plus, Somini Sengupta, our global climate reporter, will be writing a new column.
content: If you’re reading this, you know all about the stellar climate coverage done by my colleagues at The Times. Starting next week, you’ll get twice as much of it. Yup. Expect Climate Forward to land in your inbox every Tuesday and Friday. And, I’ll be your new Climate Forward guide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Gary Brooker, Singer for Procol Harum, Dies at 76
description: The pianist and singer composed the band’s music for five decades, including the hit “A Whiter Shade of Pale.”
content: Gary Brooker, the singer and pianist of the early progressive rock group Procol Harum, who co-wrote songs including “A Whiter Shade of Pale,” the improbable but overpowering hit during the 1967 Summer of Love, died on Saturday at his home in Surrey, England. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Europe prepares for the arrival of Ukrainian refugees as aid groups warn of a crisis.
description: “If war breaks out, the consequences for the Ukrainian people — and for Europe — cannot be overstated,” said one humanitarian official.
content: BRUSSELS — Humanitarian groups have warned of a major crisis for millions of people in Ukraine if Russia further invades, and the European Union says it is preparing for large numbers of displaced people if a full-on conflict breaks out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Shaw
title: A No-Cost Modernist Home, but No Takers Yet. It Needs Moving.
description: An Instagram post has boosted preservation efforts for a midcentury-modern home in Illinois. But a plan for its future would need to be in place by April 1, or it might be razed.
content: A midcentury-modern house in Illinois that has been offered at no cost since November — to anyone who can arrange to move it — is still in need of an owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Exercise Can Build Up Your Brain. Air Pollution May Negate Those Benefits.
description: People who worked out in even moderately polluted air did not show the kinds of brain improvements tied to a lower risk of dementia.
content: Work out in polluted air and you may miss out on some of the brain benefits of exercise, according to two, large-scale new studies of exercise, air quality and brain health. The studies, which involved tens of thousands of British men and women, found that, most of the time, people who ran and rode vigorously had larger brain volumes and lower risks for dementia than their less active peers. But if people exercised in areas with even moderate levels of air pollution, the expected brain improvements from exercise almost disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Roy Lichtenstein’s Studio Becomes Home to an Artistic Community
description: The pop master’s estate, a longtime friend of the Whitney Museum, will donate his Greenwich Village studio to the museum’s Independent Study Program. It will open next year.
content: Along two walls runs a floor-to-ceiling easel system designed to drip any excess paint away from the canvas, onto the floor. Wooden shelves still hold glass Mason jars full of Roy Lichtenstein’s old paints, their colors ranging from scarlet to mustard to periwinkle. It was here that the ponytailed pop master worked on the reflections series, the interior series, sculptural interpretations of his 1960s brushstroke series and “Landscapes in Chinese Style.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Ukraine’s State of Emergency
description: Bracing for war as Vladimir Putin appears undeterred by initial sanctions.
content: In its most dire assessment yet, the Pentagon said on Wednesday that 80 percent of the 190,000 Russian troops and separatist forces in or near Ukraine are in combat-ready positions, and that a full-scale military assault is most likely imminent. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: How China Under Xi Jinping Is Turning Away From the World
description: Global engagement has helped the nation prosper. But now, its leader seems intent on recasting the meeting of minds and cultures as a zero-sum clash.
content: The miracle of modern China was built on global connections, a belief that sending young people, companies and future leaders to soak up the outside world was the route from impoverishment to power. Now, emboldened by its transformation, the country is shunning the influences and ideas that nourished its rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Group Carrying Nazi Flag Interrupts Reading in Rhode Island
description: The Red Ink Community Library was hosting a reading of “The Communist Manifesto” until it was interrupted by a group whose members shouted slurs and banged on the windows.
content: A reading at a storefront library in Providence, R.I., was interrupted on Monday night, when a group of people carrying a flag with a swastika banged on the windows of the building, shouted slurs and chanted “white power.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Exposing the Heart in a Brutal Dance of Love
description: L-E-V, led by Sharon Eyal and Gai Behar, returns to the Joyce Theater with an evening-length work.
content: Sometimes it’s hard to feel what you know a choreographer wants you to feel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: The Dinosaur Age May Have Ended in Springtime
description: A new study examining fossils of fish suggests animals were wiped out by a massive meteor at a time when they were just emerging from hibernation and having offspring.
content: The dinosaur-killing meteor hit in spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Richard Pérez-Peña, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Anton Troianovski
title: U.S. and Allies Impose Sanctions on Russia as Biden Condemns ‘Invasion’ of Ukraine
description: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that more sanctions would follow if he did not withdraw his forces and engage in diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies on Tuesday swiftly imposed economic sanctions on Russia for what President Biden denounced as the beginning of an “invasion of Ukraine,” unveiling a set of coordinated punishments as Western officials confirmed that Russian forces had begun crossing the Ukrainian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Texas Governor Pushes to Investigate Medical Treatments for Trans Youth as ‘Child Abuse’
description: While it’s unclear whether the order could be enforced, medical providers and child welfare advocates condemned the move as dangerous.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott told state health agencies in Texas on Tuesday that medical treatments provided to transgender adolescents, widely considered to be the standard of care in medicine, should be classified as “child abuse” under existing state law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sunita Puri
title: We Must Learn to Look at Grief, Even When We Want to Run Away
description: The suffering that Covid wrought can unite us.
content: Months ago, over Zoom, I told a patient’s wife that her husband was dying of Covid-19. She’d last seen him six weeks earlier when he first entered the hospital, but visitor restrictions had prevented her from being at his bedside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Binelli
title: The Waco Biker Shootout Left Nine Dead. Why Was No One Convicted?
description: How 177 arrests led to no convictions — a tangled, seven-year tale of prosecutorial hubris and tenacious defense.
content: If you ask Paul Looney, a Houston defense attorney, about the Twin Peaks biker case, he’ll tell you there’s one person who knows more about it than anyone else alive: his trial-preparation specialist, Roxanne Avery. An entire wall of her home office in Norman, Okla., is covered with wallet-size mug shots of the nearly 200 bikers arrested, as well as photographs of the nine men who died that day, seven years ago, after a violent brawl in a Waco parking lot. Each picture is layered with Post-it Notes and details about the subjects: ages, road names (Cheech, Chain, Drama, Sidetrack, Saint, Mad Dog, Pee Paw, Bubba, Bubba Earl, Bashful, Yogi, Reno, Creeper, Grumpy Dan), club affiliations, ranks, descriptions of injuries (“Bullet entered neck, partially exited”; “Paralyzed from the waist down”; “DEAD”) and any other pertinent information (“I met him March 2018”; “9mm Glock”; “U.S. Army — 2 tours Iraq”; “Convicted felon”; “Shot dog?”; “Did not see anything”; “Graduate Baylor University w/ English degree”). Point to a random photograph, and Avery will generally be able to squint and tell you something about the biker in question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: This Is a Moment for America to Believe in Itself Again
description: Our greatest moments came not when we asked “Who are we?” but when we asked “Who but us?”
content: Central to much of the skepticism regarding America’s involvement in the crisis in Ukraine is the question, “Who are we?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Downey, Mark Boyer and Taras Ratushnyy
title: Ukraine’s Power Gamble: Can It Survive Without Russian Energy?
description: As Ukraine braces for an all-out conflict with Russia, it’s testing its ability to disconnect from Russian power supplies for three days, starting Feb. 24. Experts warn the timing could be risky.
content: As Ukraine braces for an all-out conflict with Russia, it’s testing its ability to disconnect from Russian power supplies for three days, starting Feb. 24. Experts warn the timing could be risky.

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 True-Crime Podcasts: When Love Is a Dangerous Con Game
description: In these shows, the promise of “happily ever after” turns into a nightmare, with stories of abusers who ruthlessly exploit their victims’ desire for love.
content: From cold-case investigations like Serial to chatty formats like My Favorite Murder, the true-crime genre has played a key role in podcasting’s journey to the mainstream. And within the category, there’s a vast subgenre of crime shows that start out as love stories. Since true-crime audiences skew female, and women are statistically in more danger from their partners than anyone else, it’s unsurprising that so many hit shows focus on women’s most primal fears about men, and about the worst things that can happen when you make the choice to trust someone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Ebony’s archives offer stewed chicken and dumplings, honey-glazed carrots, and more recipes to try very soon.
content: Good morning. In The Times this week, Kayla Stewart took readers on a reporter’s tour of the Ebony test kitchen, which closed in 2010 and was almost destroyed by developers in Chicago before being saved, restored and now presented, in all its ’70s glory, as part of “African/American: Making the Nation’s Table,” an exhibition that opens on Feb. 23 at the Africa Center at Aliko Dangote Hall in Harlem.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Ukraine Crisis: Will Sanctions Against Russia Work?
description: A reader calls for stronger action; another urges that China impose sanctions. Also: Dr. Paul Farmer; breast cancer; funeral expenses; the Trump G.O.P.
